abstract: A government spokesman said the young American who died less than a week after he was released from North Korean captivity had been well cared for.

abstract: Protesters are pressing the government to push back against Freeport-McMoRan, a U.S. mining giant, and to regain control of natural resources.

abstract: Some Mexican men, concerned that their macho views have harmed their relationships with women, are trying group therapy. Will that change the culture?

abstract: La Meute started a year and a half ago in Quebec to oppose what it calls “invasive political Islam.” Now, its social media campaign has more than 50,000 followers.

abstract: Dedicated video streaming platforms like YouTube and Twitch are looking for ways to sweeten the deal for streamers so they produce more live content.

abstract: The potential perils that come with broad access to consumers have led companies to take it very seriously.

abstract: Authorities are urging worried residents to stop killing monkeys, which experts say can serve as beacons for where the virus is spreading.

abstract: Volatile wages, owing in part to undependable schedules, are one factor increasing economic anxiety even with unemployment at a post-recession low.

headline: Trump Organization to Go Budget Friendly With ‘American Idea’ Hotel Chain
abstract: The idea for the down-market chain with a patriotic flair crystallized on the campaign trail, and the hotels may benefit from the president’s appeal in conservative areas beyond big cities.

headline: Anthony Scaramucci, Hedge Fund Showman, Finds Himself in Limbo
abstract: After selling his stake in SkyBridge Capital to a group of investors, Mr. Scaramucci expected to join the Trump administration. The job offer never came.

headline: Ruth Sulzberger Holmberg, Newspaper Publisher Born for the Job, Dies at 96
abstract: A member of the family that controls The New York Times, Mrs. Holmberg challenged racial barriers, political skulduggery and environmental adversaries as publisher of The Chattanooga Times.

headline: Did the Jack Welch Model Sow Seeds of G.E.’s Decline?
abstract: Mr. Welch’s successor, Jeffrey R. Immelt, failed to capture the same leadership aura. But it may be that the idea of a conglomerate was unsustainable.

headline: The New Gilded Age in Philanthropy
abstract: “The Givers” details how difficult it can be to give away a lot of money, but its arguments against the “creeping plutocracy” are less compelling.

headline: WinView, a Sports Betting Start-Up, Raises $12 Million
abstract: The new investors represent the latest show of support for a company that lets users make free wagers on major games in real time.

headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Clear First Hurdle in Stress Tests
abstract: The banks’ ease in passing the initial part of the examinations has led supporters to argue for less stringent restrictions.

headline: Western Nations Worry That Children Won’t Be Better Off
abstract: A survey by the Pew Research Center found more financial optimism in the developing world and in Russia than in the United States and Western Europe.

headline: Uber’s Lesson: Silicon Valley’s Start-Up Machine Needs Fixing
abstract: Travis Kalanick, who stepped down as Uber’s C.E.O., had many enablers who turned a blind eye to the company’s faults because it was growing quickly.

headline: Movers: G.M. Shareholders Reject Einhorn
abstract: General Motors holds its annual meeting in Detroit, while a German online-ordering company plans an initial public offering in Frankfurt.

headline: State and Local Tax Deduction: An Item Blurring Party Lines
abstract: White House and congressional proposals would eliminate the provision, challenging tradition and bipartisan defenders in wealthy and populous states.

headline: Amid Brick-and-Mortar Travails, a Tipping Point for Amazon in Apparel
abstract: Over the years, the online giant has picked off different retail businesses, from books to electronics. Now apparel sellers are starting to succumb.

headline: Roger Ailes: The Man Who Mined a Divided America
abstract: The Fox News creator made a fortune creating a cultural safe space for Americans pining for the way things were.

headline: Education Dept. Keeps Obama Plan to Streamline Loan System
abstract: The department, led by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, will carry out an Obama-era plan to streamline the federal system for administering $1.3 trillion in student loans.

headline: Hulu Names Its First Chief Content Officer
abstract: The streaming service hired Joel Stillerman, who has been the head of programming at AMC since 2008, overseeing hits like “The Walking Dead.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Chemical Consolidation
abstract: Huntsman Corporation has agreed to a merger with Clariant of Switzerland, a deal that would create a behemoth worth about $14 billion.

headline: Real Estate’s New Normal: Homeowners Staying Put
abstract: Low interest rates helped millions buy homes after the recession. With rates rising, many feel locked in, with little upside to moving.

headline: China Sentences Phan Phan-Gillis, U.S. Businesswoman, in Spying Case
abstract: Ms. Phan-Gillis was convicted of espionage dating to the 1990s. Her lawyer hoped she would be deported before serving her three-and-a-half-year term.

headline: How Much Did That Zipper Cost? With Transparency Pricing, You Know Everything
abstract: Some online retailers have taken to explaining in exhaustive detail how much their wares cost to make, so consumers know what they are paying for.

headline: How a Projector Can Substitute for a Television Set
abstract: While projectors cannot replace TVs in all situations, they could be a space-saving option for the times when only a big image will do.

headline: The Fallout From a Global Cyberattack: ‘A Battle We’re Fighting Every Day’
abstract: Two prestigious Chinese universities, a movie theater chain in South Korea and Japanese automakers were affected, but copycat variants did not seem to have materialized.

headline: In Towns Already Hit by Steel Mill Closings, a New Casualty: Retail Jobs
abstract: Thousands of workers face unemployment as retailers struggle to adapt to online shopping. But even as e-commerce grows, it isn’t absorbing these workers.

headline: Wireless Ambitions Meet Corporate Realities
abstract: Any tie-up involving the moguls John C. Malone, Brian Roberts and Masayoshi Son is likely to be ungainly.

headline: How Australia Bungled Its $36 Billion High-Speed Internet Rollout
abstract: Its businesses and consumers burdened with some of the developed world’s slowest speeds, the country is a cautionary tale about big-money ambitions.

headline: After London Attack, Trump Again the Center of Partisan Media Combat
abstract: News organizations turned against each other as Fox News anchors called on CNN to punish its host Reza Aslan for profane remarks about President Trump.

headline: Movers: Buffett on IBM, Oil and Jobs
abstract: We’re following major developments in the markets throughout the day. Check here for the latest updates.

headline: Wall Street Journal Said to Reduce Print Operations Outside U.S.
abstract: The Journal will greatly curtail publication of its print newspaper in Europe and scale back its operation in Asia, according to two people familiar with its plans.

headline: On Succession, ValueAct Hedge Fund Practices What It Preaches
abstract: In handing the reins to his longtime deputy, the firm’s chief executive, Jeffrey Ubben, is promoting a type of continuity that is rare in the hedge fund world.

headline: Barclays’s Latest Problem: Questions on Chief’s Judgment
abstract: James E. Staley has brought vitality to the troubled bank, but two episodes have given rise to shareholder protests and multiple investigations.

headline: Morning Agenda: Third Point Sets Sights on Nestlé
abstract: The hedge fund mogul Daniel S. Loeb has called on the Swiss food giant to shed its stake in L’Oréal and broadly shake up its strategy.

headline: Christopher Dodd to Step Down as Top Lobbyist for Movie Industry
abstract: Mr. Dodd, a former Democratic senator from Connecticut, will be succeeded in September as Hollywood’s top lobbyist by Charles H. Rivkin, a former United States ambassador.

headline: Cellphone Roaming Charges End in Europe. Many Respond With a Yawn.
abstract: Many Europeans rarely travel outside their nation’s borders, and some who do expect carriers to increase other fees instead.

headline: A Price Amazon Is Content to Keep High: $1,000 a Share
abstract: As big tech companies continue to assert their influence, a handful of businesses are dominating both in sales and on Wall Street.

headline: Want to Buy a Home? Beware: It’s a Seller’s Market
abstract: Homeowners are staying put longer than they used to, which has led to a tight supply of houses for sale, particularly in hot markets like Denver.

headline: Apple, Moving In on Prestige TV, Poaches Two Sony Executives
abstract: The company’s hiring of two respected leaders, who cultivated shows like “Breaking Bad” at Sony, signaled to Hollywood that Apple is serious about original programming.

headline: Putting the Front Desk in the Hotel Guest’s Pocket
abstract: For everything from requesting extra towels to opening doors, hotels offer apps and technology to keep customers happy and coming back.

headline: Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski of ‘Morning Joe’ Are Engaged
abstract: The couple had never publicly discussed their romantic relationship, though many people had speculated about it.

headline: At Last, Jeff Bezos Offers a Hint of His Philanthropic Plans
abstract: People have wondered if the Amazon chief was waiting until retirement to make a big charitable splash. In a tweet, he solicited ideas from the public.

headline: Wells Fargo Whistle-Blowers’ Fate Becomes Just a Footnote
abstract: After a scandal involving fraudulent accounts, the bank insists that employees can safely report wrongdoing. But its inquiry into past cases isn’t encouraging.

headline: Led by Rachel Maddow, MSNBC Surges to Unfamiliar Spot: No. 1 in Prime Time
abstract: During May, MSNBC, the cable news channel, topped its rivals in prime-time viewership among a crucial age group.

headline: Before You Pay for Financial Advice, Read This Guide
abstract: Many people turn to financial advisers when they want to ease anxieties about a big money question. Here’s what to ask yourself when choosing a pro.

headline: Supreme Court Casts Doubts on a Potent S.E.C. Weapon
abstract: A recent decision will now require the agency to seek disgorgement within five years of a violation, and the fine print is raising more questions.

headline: Take a Load Off. The Robots That Fold Laundry Are Coming.
abstract: The robots Laundroid and FoldiMate will fold a load of laundry on their own — albeit rather slowly. They are coming to market soon, their makers say.

headline: Ukraine Cyberattack Was Meant to Paralyze, not Profit, Evidence Shows
abstract: Pinpointing the initial targets of the assault — Ukrainian accountants who use a tax preparation software required by the government — was a major clue.
